Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14 provides that a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the rented premises is liable for actual and consequential damages, or at least three months’ rent, whichever is greater.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: Venue is proper in the Dorchester Division of the Boston Municipal Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §2, because the property that is the subject of this action is located within this division.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 239, §8A and G.L. c. 111, §127L, adequate heat is a condition of habitability and a required housing standard in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127L.proposition: Under G.L. c. 239, §8A and G.L. c. 111, §127L, adequate heat is a condition of habitability and a required housing standard in Massachusetts.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.201.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §410.201, which requires that every dwelling be heated to maintain temperatures of at least 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F at all other hours.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case recognizes that failure to supply heat (and related services) can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but Blackett itself concerns noise from a lounge, not a landlord’s failure to maintain heat after notice. The opinion cites earlier Massachusetts cases, including one about failure to install a heating system, as examples of substantial interference, but it does not itself hold that failure to maintain heat constitutes such interference. Thus, it indirectly references heat-related violations but is not direct authority for the specific heat-maintenance proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). … Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33-34 (1933) (failure to install necessary heating system, as agreed).”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 and interference with quiet enjoyment, but the facts and analysis involve repeated sewage flooding, not failure to maintain heat. The court’s reasoning centers on flooding as the interference with quiet enjoyment and on the landlord’s duty to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions. It therefore supports the broader idea that serious sanitary defects can constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment, but it does not specifically address or establish any rule about failure to maintain heat constituting such interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Foster v. Hyman, 346 Mass. 88 (1963).proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Foster v. Hyman, 346 Mass. 88 (1963).support_reasoning: The case concerns a landowner’s claim for injunctive relief and damages arising from a neighbor’s trespass and excavation on adjoining land. It addresses trespass, diminution in property value, and the availability of injunctive versus monetary relief, not landlord-tenant duties, heat, or interference with quiet enjoyment. There is no discussion of failure to maintain heat or of substantial interference with quiet enjoyment, so the opinion does not support the stated proposition.
Foster v. Hyman, 346 Mass. 88 (1963).relevant_excerpt: "The defendants in the Chesarone case had constructed a drain which discharged ‘surface water’ onto the plaintiff’s land, thereby flooding it. The trespass there was a ‘continuing’ one which effectively denied the plaintiff the full use of his land and an injunction was a proper remedy to protect his right to the future enjoyment of his land. Unlike that case, the master’s reports before us point out that the rights of the plaintiffs to the future use of their land are in no way jeopardized."

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does address substantial interference with quiet enjoyment, but only in the context of drug-related criminal activity and lack of security measures in common areas, not failure to maintain heat or other physical conditions of the premises. Nowhere does the opinion discuss heat, heating systems, or lack of heat as a basis for quiet enjoyment; its holding on quiet enjoyment concerns the landlord’s omission in addressing third-party criminal conduct. Thus it does not support the specific proposition that failure to maintain heat constitutes such an interference.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. . . . If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and orders declaratory, injunctive, and damages relief on that basis. The opinion emphasizes that intent is not required and that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct and its natural and probable consequences, thereby recognizing lack of heat as a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that failure to maintain heat, despite notice, can constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ordering that heat be provided… and (c) an assessment of damages…”}

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not address failure to maintain heat or any facts about lack of heat; it is about lead paint liability and whether violation of the lead paint statute, by itself, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The case generally discusses that negligent failure to repair known defects can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not itself hold that failure to maintain heat after notice constitutes substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus it does not directly support the specific heating-related proposition for which it is cited.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not involve or mention any failure to maintain heat, nor does it find any substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Instead, the court affirms the trial judge’s finding that there was no breach of quiet enjoyment because the landlord promptly remedied the cited conditions. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that a landlord’s failure to maintain heat, after notice, constitutes a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. … We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. … The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust.raw_text: Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018)
Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that loss of heat and hot water after the landlord has notice is a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability and entitles the tenant to rent abatement, regardless of landlord fault or reasonable repair efforts. However, the opinion is framed entirely in warranty/contract and statutory rent-abatement terms, not in terms of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or “substantial interference” with quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports liability and rent abatement for failure to maintain heat after notice, but not specifically under the quiet-enjoyment doctrine referenced in the proposition.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We…hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent.”

Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain heat, despite notice, constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, as recognized in multiple decisions of the Massachusetts courts, including:
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).support_reasoning: This decision concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common‑law contract and quasi‑contract claims for unpaid wages. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, heat, quiet enjoyment, or any conditions‑of‑tenancy issues. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that failure to maintain heat constitutes a substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).relevant_excerpt: In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not.
